TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a citizen of GPE , born in DATE and living in GPE . He is represented before the Court by PERSON PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE , GPE .
The respondent Government are represented by their agent , Mr PERSON PERSON of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On DATE the applicant came to GPE . On DATE he approached the police and requested asylum . He presented himself as PERSON , a NORP national . He alleged that he had just arrived and that he was not in possession of any identification papers . Pending the examination of his request for asylum the applicant was detained until DATE under section CARDINAL of LAW ( GPE ) .

During this period of time the applicant was interviewed by the police on DATE and DATE . He explained , among other things , that on CARDINAL DATE unknown armed men invaded the house of his family in GPE , the capital of GPE , and shot his parents and his brothers . He managed to escape . He could not give specific details regarding his journey to GPE , save that he went to GPE first and , from there , he went as a stowaway on a ship to a port in some country where CARDINAL girls helped him to a railway station and paid for his ticket .

On DATE the aliens authorities ( NORP for GPE ) decided not to grant the applicant refugee status , the reason being that there were insufficient evidence to prove that the applicant was in fact a NORP national , especially as he did not speak kinyawanda , the main language in GPE ; his general knowledge of GPE seemed very limited compared with the information given by the applicant that he had attended school there for DATE ; the applicant had not been involved with the NORP authorities in any way either in the political or the penal system ; and finally the only reason given by the applicant for the asylum request was his fear concerning the general situation in GPE .

This decision was upheld on appeal by ORG ( PERSON ) on DATE with the same reasoning and a deportation order was given with the deadline for departure being DATE . It was stressed that if the applicant proved unwilling to leave the country the deportation order would be enforced .

This led the applicant to apply on DATE to ORG for exceptional leave to remain in GPE . ORG refused this request on DATE but postponed the deadline for departure until DATE . Furthermore , the Ministry referred part of the application to the aliens authorities for further consideration . On DATE the aliens authorities rejected the application . It does not appear that the applicant appealed against this decision .

As the applicant had no travel documents it turned out to be difficult for the police authorities to enforce the deportation order . Thus , the applicant was requested to attend further interviews with the police authorities in order to gather sufficient information to determine the applicant ’s home country and , subsequently , to obtain the necessary travel documents .
The applicant was requested to attend interviews on DATE , CARDINAL DATE , CARDINAL DATE , DATE , CARDINAL May and DATE as well as on DATE , DATE and CARDINAL DATE .

The applicant did not attend the interviews scheduled for DATE , CARDINAL DATE and CARDINAL DATE . The ORG allege that at the interview held on DATE a language test had to be interrupted as the applicant did not co - operate . The applicant disputes this allegation , claiming that he did complete the test . At the interview held on DATE , in order to try to confirm the information given by the applicant on his nationality , the police arranged a telephone conversation between the applicant and representatives at ORG in GPE .

On DATE the police took action under section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL of LAW imposing on the applicant a duty to report in person DATE at TIME to a police unit connected to an asylum centre in GPE . It was explained to the applicant that failure to report might result in his detention . At the time the applicant was living some distance from GPE in another asylum centre in GPE . The applicant complained in vain about this action to ORG .

The applicant did not report on DATE . Thus , on CARDINAL DATE , the police drew the applicant ’s attention to the possible consequences of noncompliance with the duty to report . The applicant failed to report from CARDINAL DATE until DATE . On DATE the police turned up at the centre where the applicant was living , and with the assistance of an interpreter yet another interview was held , which included telephone conversations between the applicant and representatives at ORG in GPE and in GPE in order to try to determine the applicant ’s nationality . These telephone calls did not , however , resolve the question of his nationality . The police pointed out once again the possible consequences of noncompliance with the duty to report . Nevertheless , the applicant did not report from CARDINAL to DATE .
On DATE the police decided to take the applicant into custody pursuant to LAW , section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL cf . section CARDINAL , subsection , CARDINAL .

On DATE ORG ( kriminalretten ) found the detention to be in accordance with the provisions of LAW . On appeal , this decision was upheld on DATE by ORG of Eastern Denmark ( PERSON ) , finding that there was no basis for assuming that the reference in section DATE to the measures referred to in section CARDINAL did not include all measures mentioned in section CARDINAL , including the measures pursuant to the latter ’s subsection CARDINAL . In this respect ORG had regard to the wording of LAW , section DATE , subsection CARDINAL , the preparatory rules regarding section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL , and the fact that Act no . CARDINAL of DATE did not amend section DATE . Furthermore , the High Court emphasised that the applicant had not complied at all with the duty to report though the consequences thereof on CARDINAL occasions had been stressed .
Application for leave to appeal to ORG ( Højesteret ) was refused on DATE .

During the applicant ’s detention , on DATE the police arranged a telephone conversation between the applicant and representatives at ORG in GPE in order to confirm the information given by the applicant on his NORP nationality .

Also during the applicant ’s detention , on DATE , the police arranged another language test for the applicant . An analysis of the test showed that in all probability the applicant was not from GPE as his NORP accent was believed to be of NORP origin .
The applicant was released DATE , on DATE .

Subsequently , on DATE the applicant was confronted with the result of the language test , on DATE he was interviewed by the police and on DATE having obtained his consent the applicant ’s fingerprints were sent to ORG with a view to identification by inquiry in certain NORP countries ( GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE and GPE ) . Other means of inquiry included a visit to ORG Ivory Cost on DATE during which the applicant refused to speak LANGUAGE . On DATE , however , a representative at the embassy could listen to the tape recording of the applicant ’s NORP .
On DATE a member of ORG informed the National Commissioner of Police that the applicant wanted to marry a NORP citizen for which reason he had now decided to disclose his true identity .

On DATE the applicant revealed that his name was in fact PERSON Agnissan and he was a citizen of GPE . He flew to GPE from GPE on DATE on his GPE passport . Upon his arrival in GPE airport on DATE he posted his passport back to his family in GPE .
The applicant still remains in GPE .
Section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL of LAW , which was amended by Act no . CARDINAL of DATE , reads in so far as relevant :

“ If the measures referred to in DATE are insufficient to ensure enforcement of ... deportation of an alien , who otherwise ... is not entitled to stay in GPE , the police may decide that the alien is to be detained in custody . ”
Section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL reads in so far as relevant :

“ Until a decision has been made as to whether an alien shall be expelled ... or deported ... and until such an order can be enforced , the police may decide , where it is considered necessary to ensure the alien ’s presence , that the alien must :
CARDINAL ) deposit his / her passport , other travel documents and tickets with the police ;
CARDINAL ) NORP present security fixed by the police ;
CARDINAL ) NORP take up residence in accordance with the further instructions of the police ;
CARDINAL ) NORP report to the police at specific intervals . ”
The above Act no . CARDINAL of DATE also amended section CARDINAL by adding a subsection CARDINAL . In so far as relevant section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL reads :
“ If it is considered appropriate for the purpose of ensuring the presence of an alien , the police may decide that an alien shall report to the police at regular intervals if :
CARDINAL ) NORP the alien requests asylum on arrival , or thereafter and then does not assist in clarifying the case ;
CARDINAL ) NORP the alien fails to appear for an interview with ORG or the police to which he / she was called ;
CARDINAL ) NORP the police are in charge of the alien ’s departure and the alien does not assist therein , cf . LAW , final sentence ” .

Section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL contains a duty to provide the authorities with information and to participate actively in obtaining the necessary travel documents , visa etc . and finally to co - operate physically in the deportation .
It appears from the general notes to Act No . CARDINAL of DATE which introduced inter alia subsection CARDINAL to section CARDINAL ) :

“ To prevent abuse of the permit system of LAW , it is furthermore important to make it as unattractive as possible to aliens whose applications for a residence permit are being examined to obstruct the procuring of information in a case . It is moreover important to prevent aliens whose applications for a residence permit have been finally refused from obstructing deportation from the country ...
The amendments proposed are intended to motivate such persons to assist in deportation from GPE . ”
It appears from the detailed notes regarding section DATE , subsection CARDINAL :
“ The intention of the amendment is to allow for systematic application of a duty to report ( DATE , if necessary ) .

If the measures referred to in LAW are insufficient to ensure enforcement of refusal of entry , expulsion or deportation , the court will be able to detain an alien , cf . in detail section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL , first sentence . Part of this assessment might be whether , as a less coercive measure , a duty to report may be imposed pursuant to the proposed provision in DATE , subsection CARDINAL , and whether the alien has violated a decision to that effect ”
